Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 400-MHz NMR Spectrometer with Nitrogen-Cooled Cryoprobe
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. The University of Iowa is acquiring a 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer equipped with an inverse probe and a liquid-nitrogen cooled probe. The instrumentation supports Professors James Gloer, Leonard MacGillivray, Santhana Velupillai, Ned Bowden, Scott Daly and other colleagues. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as permitting study of biologically relevant species. In general, NMR spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution and nearby institutions such as Augustana College, as well as Des Moines Area, Kirkwood, Indian Hills and Iowa Valley community colleges and some industrial partners.

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts the discovery of bioactive natural products and the analyses of environmental degradation products of steroids and other pharmaceuticals, as well as the studies on the role of hydrogen sulfide and its controlled release in agriculture using dithiophosphates. The instrumentation is also utilized for studying synthetic coordination chemistry and ligand design for carbon dioxide reduction and separation of actinides from lanthanides, and for the development of asymmetric synthetic strategies with applications to bioactive molecules relevant to human health. In addition, it provides information to understand the disposition and toxicity of environmental pollutants and their biotransformation products, and for the analyses of products formed from template-directed synthesis of complex molecules in the solid state. The NMR spectrometer is also used to develop catalytic transformations and strategies for bond activation and to study boron-mediated chemistry, exemplified by nitrene formation to generate amines through carbonâ€“hydrogen functionalization processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This major research instrumentation grant enabled acquisition of a state-of-the-art 400-MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer with an accompanying liquid nitrogen-cooled cryoprobe that supports advances in fundamental scientific research at the University of Iowa (UI). The instrument is housed in the UI High Resolution NMR Facility, which provides a well- established platform for instrument management, user training, and accessibility for the University campus and surrounding community. This spectrometer effectively replaced an outdated instrument with far more modern equipment that incorporates several new technologies that were not previously available on campus, and therefore represent important infrastructure enhancements at the University.

This NMR instrument is utilized by researchers as an essential tool for unambiguous structural identification of small molecules either in pure form or as components of mixtures.  Several thousand samples have already been analyzed since its installation.  More than 55 UI researchers across 15 individual research groups have been trained to use this instrument, and this number continues to grow.  Their training includes safe operating procedures, familiarization with data acquisition software, optimization of data quality, and data analysis.  Users schedule instrument time using an on-line scheduling system. Most of these users are graduate students and postdoctoral associates for whom NMR spectroscopy is a vital tool for their research progress.  The focus on hands-on operation by these users is an important broader impact feature, as it is an important general component of the education of these young scientists.  Fifteen graduate students who used this spectrometer extensively for NMR analysis completed their Ph.D. dissertations during the award period, and many more students will similarly benefit in future years.  Facility staff assist users in running more specialized experiments, and also collect data for users whose NMR needs are less frequent.  This instrument also provides broader impact by serving as a valuable resource to surrounding communities, including local companies that need occasional NMR support to help in compound identification. In addition, the spectrometer has been included as a highlight of new graduate student orientation, in tours involving prospective undergraduate students and their parents, and in demonstration sessions for undergraduate chemistry courses.  Advanced undergraduate students and teaching assistants also use the instrument to run samples to provide high-quality, real-world data for selected chemistry courses.

Although all of the users of the instrument have research that is focused on various aspects of chemistry, their projects interface with diverse, related interdisciplinary research areas such as chemical and biochemical engineering, materials science, pharmaceutics, occupational and environmental health, and ophthalmology.  Data collected using the instrument have enabled research progress leading to a variety of journal publications and presentations at scientific conferences, and will continue to do so well into the future.  Moreover, the much needed improvements to signal resolution, sensitivity, experimental control, and data acquisition techniques provided by this instrument have fostered the exploration of new research avenues and supported the acquisition of other research awards and grants to UI researchers.  This NMR spectrometer is a valuable resource that will continue to support the research and educational mission of the UI for years to come.
